Authors:
E. C. Yang, Kyeong Mi Kim, Su Yeon Kim, Jun Mo Lee, Ga Hun
Boo, Jung-Hyun Lee, Wendy A. Nelson, Gangman Yi, William Schmidt,
Suzanne Fredericq, Sung Min Boo, Debashish Bhattacharya, Hwan Su
Yoon
Title:
Highly Conserved mtDNA Among Multicellular Red Algae of the
Florideophyceae
Keywords:
Ordinal relationship; mitochondrial genome; phylogeny;
Rhodophyta; Rhodymeniophycidae
Abstract:
Two red algal classes, the Florideophyceae (ca. 6100 spp.)
and Bangiophyceae (ca. 150 spp.) comprise 98% of red algal diversity in
marine and freshwater habitats. Whereas these two classes form
well-supported monophyletic groups in most phylogenetic analyses,
inter-ordinal relationships remain largely unresolved, in particular in
the largest subclass Rhodymeniophycidae that includes 72% of all red
algal species. To elucidate phylogenetic relationships and to identify
major evolutionary transitions in red algae, we characterized 11 new
mitochondrial genomes (mtDNA) with representatives from five
florideophycean subclasses and all 12 orders of Rhodymeniophycidae.
Using this database that included 15 economically important species, we
performed comparative analyses of mtDNAs. Using a dataset of
concatenated proteins, we were able to resolve phylogenetic
relationships within the Rhodymeniophycidae. This organelle genome shows
46 instances of gene rearrangements including 12 that distinguish the
Bangiophyceae from the Hildenbrandiophycidae, and 5 events that
distinguish the Hildenbrandiophycidae from the Nemaliophycidae.
Lineage-specific gene losses were found for several protein-coding genes
in the Florideophyceae. Our well-sampled red algal mtDNA data show a
rapid radiation and surprisingly low gene and sequence diversity among
the morphologically divergent multicellular lineages in the “advanced”
Florideophyceae. This genome has for currently unknown reasons been
highly constrained with respect to gene content and sequence for over
500 million years of evolution.
